courseTitle: Wavelength of Light and its Effect on Phototropism

pageData.titleName2: Wavelength of Light and its Effect on Phototropism

pageData.text: To collect the maximum amount of light energy possible, plants grow so as to expose the greatest possible leaf, or photosynthetic surface, to the light source. This process is called <button class='glossary-text'>phototropism</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Positive phototropism</button> is growth toward the light; <button class='glossary-text'>negative phototropism</button> is growth away from the light. This experiment looks at various wavelengths of light and their effects on positive and negative phototropism.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 60–90 minutes + 5–8 days 
Activity 1: Day 1 – 40 minutes
                 Day 2–4 – 20 minutes each day

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Wavelength of Light and its Effect on Phototropism

text: Describe the process of <button class='glossary-text'>phototropism</button> and why it occurs.
Examine the effects of different wavelengths of light on the direction and angle of plant growth.
Identify which light colors and intensities result in and .

pageData.text: is the directional movement of plants in response to light, but many plants also exhibit photonasty, non-directional movement in response to light. One of the most dramatic examples of this is found in the house plant Maranta leuconeura, commonly called the prayer plant. The plant begins its day with leaves folded longitudinally. Throughout the day, the leaves slowly unfurl and spread out to absorb maximum light. As evening approaches, the plant moves back to its starting position, raising its leaves in a motion that resembles hands coming together in prayer, hence the nickname. This day-night cycle of movement is called nyctinastic movement and is similar in some ways to circadian rhythm in animals. Unlike phototropism, this movement does not involve cell division or elongation, but instead functions using hydraulics. The bases of the leaves have a specialized organ which allows the cells to fill with water or release water, moving the leaves with . Exactly how this is regulated and why these plants exhibit this motion is still being studied1.

1Davis, F. (2016, May 24). What do plants do at night? Understanding nyctinastic movement.
Exploring Sound and Circadian Rhythms. http://blogs.evergreen.edu/pim-group7/understanding-nyctinastic-movement/

pageData.altText: The leaves of the Maranta leuconeura plant unfurled during the daytime.

pageData.text: Plants use solar energy and electrons from water to convert atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) into sugar (glucose, C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>) and oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) in a process called photosynthesis. This is shown in the following reaction:
6 CO2 + 6 H2O Sunlight   C6H12O6 + 6 O2

White light (sunlight) is composed of light of a variety of wavelengths ranging from short wavelengths (~400–475 nm), violets and blues, to long wavelengths (~650–800 nm and longer,) reds and infrared. Green light is approximately in the middle of the spectrum, with a wavelength of ~510 nm (see Figure 1). Not all wavelengths are absorbed equally by the plant’s photosynthetic mechanism. Light is collected by a variety of pigments, the , located in the green parts of the plant. This complex collects the light reaching the plant, transforms the light energy into electrons, and transports these electrons to the photosystem, where the energy is converted to chemical energy in the form of ATP.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Electromagnetic Spectrum

pageData.text: The photosystem consists of two major complex proteins, Photosystem I and Photosystem II. Both photosystems contain , the green pigment in plants which absorbs light during photosynthesis, as one of the main components. Both collect sunlight with the help of a . This complex has different pigments which are sensitive to different wavelengths of light.

The pigments in the light-harvesting complex are what give a plant a particular color. The color that we see is the wavelength of light not used by the plant; instead, this wavelength is reflected back from the plant. Thus, if we see a plant as green, the plant has absorbed all wavelengths of light except the green. When we see a leaf as red, it is because the red light is not absorbed by the plant and is reflected back (see Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing how leaves reflect almost all green and yellow light, some orange and purple light, and absorb almost all blue, yellow, and red light

pageData.question: Some plant leaves appear red rather than green. Which light is reflected from red plant leaves?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When we see a leaf as red, it is because the red light is not absorbed by the plant and is reflected.

pageData.question: Which of the following wavelengths of light would appear red?

feedbackData.text: On the electromagnetic spectrum, long wavelengths (red and infrared) are <sup>~</sup>650–800 nm and longer.

pageData.text: In order to collect the most energy possible, plants orient themselves to expose the greatest amount of surface area, and and photosystems, to the light. To do this, plants either modify the internal water pressure, or , in the cells, or increase or decrease elongation and growth in parts of the stem or leaves.

A familiar example of the first mechanism is the sunflower. Sunflowers appear to follow the movement of the sun in the sky. In actuality the leaves surrounding the flower are aligned with the sun, and the movement of the flower is just a side effect. In order to change the angle of the leaves, the sunflower empties the vacuoles (organelles that store water, see Figure 3) on the side of the plant exposed to the sunlight, lowering the pressure in those cells.

At the same time, the vacuoles in the cells located away from the sun fill with water, increasing the turgor pressure in those cells. The result is that the plant leans in the direction of the sun. In a field of sunflowers, all the sunflowers will face the same direction. This process of orientation with respect to light on a daily cycle is called , a form of .

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram of a plant cell with major organelles labeled

pageData.text: Not all plants exhibit at the same speed as sunflowers. For most plants, alignment with the light source is a much slower process, taking days or longer. In these plants, hormonal changes in the plant encourage growth on one side of the plant, causing that portion of the plant to elongate, bending the plant. Movement toward a light source is called .

When the amount of light reaching the plant is greater than the capacity of the and photosystems, the resulting excess energy in the leaves can cause overproduction of electrons, which can damage the proteins in the plant. To avoid this, a plant moves its leaves in an angle so that less sunlight will be collected. This process is called .

Because plants have different pigments, their sensitivity to wavelengths of different colors in the spectrum is different. Plants are mostly green; green light is not absorbed well by the <button class='glossary-text'>chlorophyll</button> in the photosystems and is reflected back. Thus, a plant will exhibit weak or no phototropism in response to green light. On the other hand, plants absorb blue and red light well. Exposing plants to a blue or red light source at an angle should lead the plants to lean toward the light. This is an example of positive phototropism in response to a certain wavelength of light. In this experiment, germinated seeds will be exposed to multiple colors of light and the effects of phototropism will be analyzed.

pageData.question: What would you expect to see if a green plant is exposed to a blue light source at an angle?

options.text: The plant will move toward the light source.
The plant will move away from the light source.
The plant will match the color of the light source.
The plant will be the opposite color of that of the light source.
The plant will have no observable reaction.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Exposing plants to a blue or red-light source at an angle should lead the plants to lean toward the light (positive phototropism).

pageData.question: Plants can move in response to light by controlling which of the following organelles in certain cells?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Plants orient themselves to maximize light exposure by modifying the internal water pressure (turgor pressure) in the cells by emptying or filling the vacuoles.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, germinate the dormant seeds. In the activity, label the boxes and create light filters in the boxes. Then, add the germinated seedlings and soil to weigh boats. Next, measure the angle of seedling deviation from the vertical. Then, put the weigh boats in the boxes and place the boxes under the grow light. After 24 and 48 hours, observe the angle of growth and photograph the plants. Then, calculate positive and negative phototropism. After 72 hours, measure the angle of seedling deviation. Finally, calculate the average change in angle and graph the results.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following most accurately describes phototropism?

options.text: A plant orients its leaves away from direct sunlight during the heat of the day.
A seed planted upside down germinates with its roots growing down into the soil.
A plant uses photosynthesis to store light energy as chemical energy in sugar.
A plant elongates its stem to wrap itself around a nearby pole.
A plant changes its leaf color at sunset to absorb longer wavelengths of light.

assestmentData.question: Which of these is a large, water-collecting structure within a plant cell?
Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?

options.text: a plastic container with airtight lid
a desk lamp or grow light
a variety of vegetable or flower seeds

assestmentData.question: You will need about one week to prepare which of the following before starting the investigation?

options.text: growth chambers with different colored light sources

assestmentData.question: Which of the following parts of a plant cell absorbs light during photosynthesis?
What color is NOT absorbed well by chlorophyll?
Which color light will likely cause the plant to lean toward the light?
What mechanism allows the plant to orient themselves to expose the greatest amount of leaf surface?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Take the plastic container and place a piece of notebook or printer paper into it. Saturate the paper with tap water using a transfer pipet, and drain off any excess water.
Place ~50 seeds on the moistened piece of paper, making sure to evenly space out the seeds. Seal the plastic container with the airtight lid.
Place the container under the grow light.
Wait 5–8 days until the seeds have germinated. This will be apparent when the seed coat splits open and a short root and shoot (a little sprout) can be seen emerging from the seed.

Check the container a few times per day to make sure that the germinating seeds do not dry out. If any appear dry, use a transfer pipet to moisten the paper. Make sure to reseal the container with the airtight lid after this process.

In Activity 1, you will grow your germinated seeds in boxes with different colored light filters. You will observe the plant growth over 4 days and calculate the percent <button class='glossary-text'>phototropism</button> and angle of plant growth for each light treatment.

Label six boxes as follows:
  • white light
  • red light
  • blue light
  • yellow light
  • green light
  • high light

Using one of the light filters as a template, cut two squares from a clear plastic bag, such as the one used to hold the materials from this investigation. These will be used for the white light and the high light boxes.

Cut a hole in the long side of each box. Make sure the holes are ½ inch smaller on each side than the filters so that the filters will cover the entire hole and no light will enter through the sides of the filters.
Tape a clear filter over the hole in the boxes labeled “white light” and “high light”. Tape the appropriately colored filter over the hole of each of the other labeled boxes.

Mark one side of each weigh boat with a pen or marker. This will indicate the side of the weigh boat that will be closest to the grow light. Put a thin layer of potting soil in the bottom of each of the six weigh boats.
Using scissors, carefully cut the paper around each seedling. Using forceps, place 4–5 germinated seedlings and the attached papers in each weigh boat, spacing them out evenly.
Gently add soil to each weigh boat so that the seedlings are well-supported and stand upright. Tamp down on the soil with your fingers to pack it.

Once all plants are added to the weigh boat, orient the container so that the marked side is up. Draw a diagram of the weigh boat indicating the marked side. Record the location of each plant as a number (see figure 4). Photograph your diagrams.
pageData.altText: camera symbol
Figure 4: Example diagram of planting locations

pageData.text: Hold the protractor vertically across the weigh boat from the front to the back. Measure the angle of each seedling's deviation from the vertical. Plants that are leaning away from the front of the boat should have a negative angle, and those that lean towards the front will have a positive angle. How much plants lean to either side is not measured (see Figure 5). Record your results for each seedling in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram showing how to measure the growth angle with a protractor

pageData.text: Lettuce seedlings are fragile and very susceptible to drying out, so they are very tolerant of moisture. If they do dry out, they will wilt, and it will be impossible to observe the . Make sure they are well-watered.
For the duration of this investigation, check the plants a few times per day to make sure that they do not dry out. If any appear dry, use a transfer pipet to moisten them.
Make sure the soil is damp by moistening it with tap water using the pipet.
Close the bottom of the box and tape the flaps shut if necessary. Place one weigh boat in the bottom of each of the boxes. Align them such that the marked side is closest to the filter.
Close the top of the box so that no unfiltered light is entering the box. If necessary, secure the top with tape.

Place the grow light in such a way that the light will be ~50 cm (~20 in) from the boxes, shining into the boxes. For the “high light” treatment, place the box as close as possible to the light. Make sure not to obstruct the light to the other boxes. All boxes should be arranged so that the marked side of the weigh boat is nearest the light.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: For the next two days, open the boxes and note the direction of growth. Record this in Data Table 1. Photograph the weigh boats with their respective colored-filter boxes.
For each treatment, count the number of plants in the box that have moved toward or away from the light, and divide this number by the total number of plants in the box to calculate the percent .
% phototropism = number of plants growing toward or away from the light /total number of plants × 100

Record this data daily in Data Table 2. Count the number of plants that have moved away from the light, and divide this number by the total number of plants in the box to calculate the percent . Record this data daily in Data Table 2.

On day 4, open the boxes and carefully remove the weigh boats. Measure the angles as was done on day 1. Do not record angles for plants that are visibly wilted or dead. Record this data in Data Table 1.
Calculate the change in angle by subtracting the angle on day 1 from the angle on day 4.
To find the average change in angle for each light treatment, add all the differences calculated in step 2 and divide by the number of plants that survived. Record the averages in Data Table 3.
Create a bar graph to present the results in Data Table 3.

text: Dispose of all waste generated during the activity in the household trash. Discard water in the sink.
Return all materials belonging to the botany equipment kit to its bag.

data.title: Chlorophyll
data.content: The type of plant pigment that is green and absorbs light during photosynthesis

data.title: Heliotropism
data.content: The process of a plant turning or curving toward light on a daily cycle

data.title: Light-harvesting complex
data.content: A variety of plant pigments located in the green parts of a plant that collects light

data.title: Negative phototropism
data.content: Movement away from the light source

data.title: Phototropism
data.content: The process of a plant bending in response to the directionality of light

data.title: Turgor pressure
data.content: The internal water pressure in a cell
